RP   MOSSBAUER SPECTROSCOPY.
RX   MEDLINE=97250476; PubMed=9096332; DOI=10.1073/pnas.94.7.2981;
RA   Shanklin J., Achim C., Schmidt H., Fox B.G., Muenck E.;

RP   MUTAGENESIS OF HIS-138; HIS-142; HIS-163; HIS-168; HIS-172; HIS-173;
RP   ASP-181; HIS-308; HIS-312; HIS-315; HIS-316 AND HIS-318.
RX   MEDLINE=22689052; PubMed=12804773; DOI=10.1016/S0014-5793(03)00529-5;
RA   Shanklin J., Whittle E.;
RT   "Evidence linking the Pseudomonas oleovorans alkane omega-hydroxylase,
RT   an integral membrane diiron enzyme, and the fatty acid desaturase
RT   family.";
RL   FEBS Lett. 545:188-192(2003).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Is responsible for the initial oxidation of inactivated
CC       alkanes.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Octane + reduced rubredoxin + O(2) = 1-octanol
CC       + oxidized rubredoxin + H(2)O.
CC   -!- COFACTOR: Binds 2 Fe(3+) ions per subunit.
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Hydrocarbon metabolism; alkane degradation.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: The alkane hydroxylase consists of three components: a
CC       soluble NADH-rubredoxin reductase, a soluble rubredoxin and the
CC       integral membrane oxygenase alkB.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell inner membrane; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein (Probable).
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the fatty acid desaturase family. AlkB
CC       subfamily.

RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (2.3 ANGSTROMS) OF 154-281.
RX   MEDLINE=20351469; PubMed=10891274; DOI=10.1006/jmbi.2000.3853;
RA   Meier M., Bider M.D., Malashkevich V.N., Spiess M., Burkhard P.;
RT   "Crystal structure of the carbohydrate recognition domain of the H1
RT   subunit of the asialoglycoprotein receptor.";
RL   J. Mol. Biol. 300:857-865(2000).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Mediates the endocytosis of plasma glycoproteins to
CC       which the terminal sialic acid residue on their complex
CC       carbohydrate moieties has been removed. The receptor recognizes
CC       terminal galactose and N-acetylgalactosamine units. After ligand
CC       binding to the receptor, the resulting complex is internalized and
CC       transported to a sorting organelle, where receptor and ligand are
CC       disassociated. The receptor then returns to the cell membrane
CC       surface.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Interacts with LASS2.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q96G23:LASS2; NbExp=1; IntAct=EBI-1172335, EBI-1057080;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane; Single-pass type II membrane
CC       protein.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Expressed exclusively in hepatic parenchymal
CC       cells.
CC   -!- PTM: Phosphorylated on a cytoplasmic Ser residue.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Calcium is required for ligand binding.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 C-type lectin domain.
CC   -!- WEB RESOURCE: Name=Functional Glycomics Gateway - Glycan Binding;
CC       Note=Hepatic asialoglycoprotein receptor subunit 1;
CC       URL="http://www.functionalglycomics.org/glycomics/GBPServlet?&operationType=view&cbpId=cbp_hum_Ctlect_215";

RP   SUBCELLULAR LOCATION.
RC   STRAIN=K12 / MG1655 / ATCC 47076;
RX   PubMed=15919996; DOI=10.1126/science.1109730;
RA   Daley D.O., Rapp M., Granseth E., Melen K., Drew D., von Heijne G.;

RN   [20]
RP   STRUCTURE BY NMR OF 95-271.
RX   MEDLINE=20046441; PubMed=10580496; DOI=10.1038/46224;
RA   Rastogi V.K., Girvin M.E.;
RT   "Structural changes linked to proton translocation by subunit c of the
RT   ATP synthase.";
RL   Nature 402:263-268(1999).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Key component of the proton channel; it plays a direct
CC       role in the translocation of protons across the membrane.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: F-type ATPases have 2 components, CF(1) - the catalytic
CC       core - and CF(0) - the membrane proton channel. CF(1) has five
CC       subunits: alpha(3), beta(3), gamma(1), delta(1), epsilon(1). CF(0)
CC       has three main subunits: a(1), b(2) and c(9-12). The alpha and
CC       beta chains form an alternating ring which encloses part of the
CC       gamma chain. CF(1) is attached to CF(0) by a central stalk formed
CC       by the gamma and epsilon chains, while a peripheral stalk is
CC       formed by the delta and b chains.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell inner membrane; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ATPase A chain family.
CC   -!- CAUTION: Was originally (PubMed:6278247) proposed to be encoded
CC       from either Met-1 or Val-71 (PID CAA23521); it is now thought to
CC       start of Met-1.
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

RP   FUNCTION.
RX   PubMed=15087499; DOI=10.1073/pnas.0307709101;
RA   Zhou R., Kroos L.;
RT   "BofA protein inhibits intramembrane proteolysis of pro-sigmaK in an
RT   intercompartmental signaling pathway during Bacillus subtilis
RT   sporulation.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 101:6385-6390(2004).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Involved in the mediation of the intercompartmental
CC       coupling of pro-sigma K processing to events in the forespore.
CC       Inhibits spoIVFB-processing activity until a signal has been
CC       received from the forespore. Could inhibit spoIVFB metalloprotease
CC       activity by coordinating a zinc in spoIVFB active site, preventing
CC       access of a water molecule and the sequence of pro-sigma K, which
CC       are necessary for peptide bond hydrolysis to produce sigma-K.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Forms a complex with spoIVFA and spoIVFB localized in the
CC       mother cell membrane surrounding the forespore.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Forespore outer membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein.

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License

RN   [4]
RP   GENETIC ANALYSIS, AND SUGGESTION OF SUBUNIT.
RX   PubMed=9504916;
RA   Xie Z., Culler D., Dreyfuss B.W., Kuras R., Wollman F.-A.,
RA   Girard-Bascou J., Merchant S.;
RT   "Genetic analysis of chloroplast c-type cytochrome assembly in

RN   [5]
RP   SUBUNIT.
RC   STRAIN=137c / CC-125;
RX   PubMed=12427766; DOI=10.1074/jbc.M208651200;
RA   Hamel P.P., Dreyfuss B.W., Xie Z., Gabilly S.T., Merchant S.;
RT   "Essential histidine and tryptophan residues in CcsA, a system II
RT   polytopic cytochrome c biogenesis protein.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 278:2593-2603(2003).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Required during biogenesis of c-type cytochromes
CC       (cytochrome c6 and cytochrome f) at the step of heme attachment.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: May interact with ccsA.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Plastid, chloroplast thylakoid membrane;
CC       Multi-pass membrane protein (Probable).
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Algae lacking CCS1 are unable to grow
CC       phototrophically; they specifically accumulate apocytochrome c6
CC       and apocytochrome f.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: A mutant with a small stroma insert (ccs1-ac206)
CC       does not produce holocytochromes.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ccs1/ccsB family.

RN   [22]
RP   INVOLVEMENT IN MYCOBACTERIUM TUBERCULOSIS SUSCEPTIBILITY.
RX   PubMed=16379498; DOI=10.1371/journal.pmed.0030020;
RA   Barreiro L.B., Neyrolles O., Babb C.L., Tailleux L., Quach H.,
RA   McElreavey K., Helden P.D., Hoal E.G., Gicquel B., Quintana-Murci L.;
RT   "Promoter variation in the DC-SIGN-encoding gene CD209 is associated
RT   with tuberculosis.";
RL   PLoS Med. 3:230-235(2006).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Pathogen-recognition receptor expressed on the surface
CC       of immature dendritic cells (DCs) and involved in initiation of
CC       primary immune response. Thought to mediate the endocytosis of
CC       pathogens which are subsequently degraded in lysosomal
CC       compartments. The receptor returns to the cell membrane surface
CC       and the pathogen-derived antigens are presented to resting T-cells
CC       via MHC class II proteins to initiate the adaptive immune
CC       response. Probably recognizes in a calcium-dependent manner high
CC       mannose N-linked oligosaccharides in a variety of pathogen
CC       antigens, including HIV-1 gp120, HIV-2 gp120, SIV gp120,
CC       ebolavirus glycoproteins, cytomegalovirus gB, HCV E2, dengue virus
CC       gE, Leishmania pifanoi LPG, Lewis-x antigen in Helicobacter pylori
CC       LPS, mannose in Klebsiella pneumonae LPS, di-mannose and tri-
CC       mannose in Mycobacterium tuberculosis ManLAM and Lewis-x antigen
CC       in Schistosoma mansoni SEA.
CC   -!- FUNCTION: On DCs it is a high affinity receptor for ICAM2 and
CC       ICAM3 by binding to mannose-like carbohydrates. May act as a DC
CC       rolling receptor that mediates transendothelial migration of DC
CC       presursors from blood to tissues by binding endothelial ICAM2.
CC       Seems to regulate DC-induced T-cell proliferation by binding to
CC       ICAM3 on T-cells in the immunological synapse formed between DC
CC       and T-cells.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homotetramer. Binds to many viral surface glycoproteins
CC       such as HIV-1 gp120, HIV-2 gp120, SIV gp120, ebolavirus envelope
CC       glycoproteins, cytomegalovirus gB, HCV E2 and dengue virus major
CC       envelope protein E.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Isoform 1: Cell membrane; Single-pass type
CC       II membrane protein (Probable).
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Isoform 2: Cell membrane; Single-pass type
CC       II membrane protein (Probable).
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Isoform 3: Cell membrane; Single-pass type
CC       II membrane protein (Probable).
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Isoform 4: Cell membrane; Single-pass type
CC       II membrane protein (Probable).
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Isoform 5: Cell membrane; Single-pass type
CC       II membrane protein (Probable).
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Isoform 6: Secreted (Probable).
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Isoform 7: Secreted (Probable).
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Isoform 8: Secreted (Probable).
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Isoform 9: Secreted (Probable).
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Isoform 10: Secreted (Probable).
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Isoform 11: Secreted (Probable).
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Isoform 12: Secreted (Probable).
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=13;
CC         Comment=Additional isoforms seem to exist. Several splicing
CC         events may be used independently in a modular way. Deletion of
CC         the transmembrane domain encoding exon through alternative
CC         splicing produces soluble isoforms;
CC       Name=1; Synonyms=mDC-SIGN1A type I;
CC         IsoId=Q9NNX6-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2; Synonyms=mDC-SIGN1A type II;
CC         IsoId=Q9NNX6-2; Sequence=VSP_010049;
CC       Name=3; Synonyms=mDC-SIGN1A type III;
CC         IsoId=Q9NNX6-3; Sequence=VSP_010044;
CC       Name=4; Synonyms=mDC-SIGN1A type IV;
CC         IsoId=Q9NNX6-4; Sequence=VSP_010042;
CC       Name=5; Synonyms=mDC-SIGN1B type I;
CC         IsoId=Q9NNX6-5; Sequence=VSP_010037;
CC       Name=6; Synonyms=sDC-SIGN1A type I;
CC         IsoId=Q9NNX6-6; Sequence=VSP_010041;
CC       Name=7; Synonyms=sDC-SIGN1A type II;
CC         IsoId=Q9NNX6-7; Sequence=VSP_010038;
CC       Name=8; Synonyms=sDC-SIGN1A type III;
CC         IsoId=Q9NNX6-8; Sequence=VSP_010038, VSP_010043;
CC       Name=9; Synonyms=sDC-SIGN1A type IV;
CC         IsoId=Q9NNX6-9; Sequence=VSP_010039, VSP_010040;
CC       Name=10; Synonyms=sDC-SIGN1B type I;
CC         IsoId=Q9NNX6-10; Sequence=VSP_010037, VSP_010041;
CC       Name=11; Synonyms=sDC-SIGN1B type II;
CC         IsoId=Q9NNX6-11; Sequence=VSP_010037, VSP_010041, VSP_010047;
CC       Name=12; Synonyms=sDC-SIGN1B type III;
CC         IsoId=Q9NNX6-12; Sequence=VSP_010037, VSP_010041, VSP_010048,
CC                                   VSP_010050;
CC       Name=13; Synonyms=sDC-SIGN1A type IV;
CC         IsoId=Q9NNX6-13; Sequence=VSP_010037, VSP_010041, VSP_010045,
CC                                   VSP_010046;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Predominantly expressed in dendritic cells and
CC       in DC-residing tissues. Also found in placental macrophages,
CC       endothelial cells of placental vascular channels, peripheral blood
CC       mononuclear cells, and THP-1 monocytes.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The tandem repeat domain, also called neck domain,
CC       mediates oligermerization.
CC   -!- POLYMORPHISM: Genetic variations in CD209 determine Mycobacterium
CC       tuberculosis susceptibility [MIM:607948].
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: In vitro, is a receptor for HIV-1 and transmits
CC       HIV-1 either in trans without DC infection, or in cis following a
CC       DC infection to permissive T-cells to induce a robust infection.
CC       Bound HIV-1 remains infectious over a prolonged period of time and
CC       it is proposed that bound HIV-1 is not degraded but protected in
CC       non-lysosomal acidic organelles within the DCs close to the cell
CC       membrane thus contributing to the HIV-1 infectious potential
CC       during transport by DCs from the periphery to lymphoid organs.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 C-type lectin domain.
CC   -!- WEB RESOURCE: Name=Wikipedia; Note=DC-SIGN entry;
CC       URL="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DC-SIGN";
CC   -!- WEB RESOURCE: Name=Functional Glycomics Gateway - Glycan Binding;
CC       Note=DC-SIGN;
CC       URL="http://www.functionalglycomics.org/glycomics/GBPServlet?&operationType=view&cbpId=cbp_hum_Ctlect_00121";

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Probable pathogen-recognition receptor involved in
CC       peripheral immune surveillance in liver. May mediate the
CC       endocytosis of pathogens which are subsequently degraded in
CC       lysosomal compartments. Probably recognizes in a calcium-dependent
CC       manner high mannose N-linked oligosaccharides in a variety of
CC       pathogen antigens, including HIV-1 gp120, HIV-2 gp120, SIV gp120,
CC       ebolavirus glycoproteins, HCV E2, and human SARS coronavirus
CC       protein S. Is a receptor for ICAM3, probably by binding to
CC       mannose-like carbohydrates. Is presumably a coreceptor for the
CC       SARS coronavirus.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homotetramer. Binds to many viral surface glycoproteins
CC       such as HIV-1 gp120, HIV-2 gp120, SIV gp120, ebolavirus
CC       glycoproteins, HCV E2, and human SARS coronavirus S protein.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Isoform 1: Cell membrane; Single-pass type
CC       II membrane protein (Potential).
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Isoform 2: Cell membrane; Single-pass type
CC       II membrane protein (Potential).
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Isoform 3: Cell membrane; Single-pass type
CC       II membrane protein (Potential).
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Isoform 5: Secreted (Potential).
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Isoform 6: Secreted (Potential).
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Isoform 7: Secreted (Potential).
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Isoform 10: Secreted (Potential).
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=11;
CC         Comment=Additional isoforms seem to exist. Several splicing
CC         events may occur independently in a modular way. Deletion of the
CC         transmembrane domain encoding exon through alternative splicing
CC         produces soluble isoforms;
CC       Name=1; Synonyms=mDC-SIGN2 type I;
CC         IsoId=Q9H2X3-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2; Synonyms=mDC-SIGN2 type III, mDC-SIGN2 type IV;
CC         IsoId=Q9H2X3-2; Sequence=VSP_010063, VSP_010064;
CC       Name=3; Synonyms=mDC-SIGN2 type V;
CC         IsoId=Q9H2X3-3; Sequence=VSP_010065, VSP_010066;
CC       Name=4; Synonyms=mDC-SIGN2 type VI;
CC         IsoId=Q9H2X3-4; Sequence=VSP_010060, VSP_010062, VSP_010065,
CC                                  VSP_010066;
CC       Name=5; Synonyms=sDC-SIGN2 type I;
CC         IsoId=Q9H2X3-5; Sequence=VSP_010058, VSP_010061, VSP_010062;
CC       Name=6; Synonyms=sDC-SIGN2 type II;
CC         IsoId=Q9H2X3-6; Sequence=VSP_010058, VSP_010063, VSP_010064;
CC       Name=7; Synonyms=sDC-SIGN2 type III;
CC         IsoId=Q9H2X3-7; Sequence=VSP_010058, VSP_010059;
CC       Name=8;
CC         IsoId=Q9H2X3-8; Sequence=VSP_010061;
CC       Name=9;
CC         IsoId=Q9H2X3-9; Sequence=VSP_010056, VSP_010065, VSP_010066;
CC       Name=10;
CC         IsoId=Q9H2X3-10; Sequence=VSP_010056, VSP_010057, VSP_010063,
CC                                   VSP_010064;
CC       Name=11;
CC         IsoId=Q9H2X3-11; Sequence=VSP_017289;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Predominantly highly expressed in liver
CC       sinusoidal endothelial cells and in lymph node. Found in placental
CC       endothelium but not in macrophages. Expressed in type II alveolar
CC       cells and lung endothelial cells.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The tandem repeat domain, also called neck domain,
CC       mediates oligermerization.
CC   -!- POLYMORPHISM: The number of repeats in the tandem repeat domain is
CC       shown to vary between 3 and 9 per allele thus contributing to a
CC       further variability in addition to alternative splicing. The shown
CC       7 repeats-containing form has been shown to be the most frequent
CC       one (53.9%) in a study with 350 Caucasian individuals.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: In vitro, is a receptor for HIV-1 and transmits
CC       HIV-1 to permissive T-cells.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 C-type lectin domain.
CC   -!- WEB RESOURCE: Name=Functional Glycomics Gateway - Glycan Binding;
CC       Note=DC-SIGNR;
CC       URL="http://www.functionalglycomics.org/glycomics/GBPServlet?&operationType=view&cbpId=cbp_hum_Ctlect_00122";

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Visual signal transduction is mediated by a G-protein
CC       coupled cascade using cGMP as second messenger. This protein can
CC       be activated by cGMP which leads to an opening of the cation
CC       channel and thereby causing a depolarization of rod
CC       photoreceptors.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homotetramer or higher oligomer.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Rod cells in the retina.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the cyclic nucleotide-gated cation channel
CC       (TC 1.A.1.5) family.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 cyclic nucleotide-binding domain.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: This protein is involved in several diverse cellular
CC       processes, such as the functioning of acetohydroxyacid synthetase
CC       I, in the biosynthesis of isoleucine and valine, the traJ protein
CC       activation activity for tra gene expression in F plasmid, and the
CC       synthesis, translocation, or stability of cell envelope proteins.
CC       Activates cpxR by phosphorylation.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: ATP + protein L-histidine = ADP + protein N-
CC       phospho-L-histidine.

CC       protein.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: One gap junction consists of a cluster of closely packed
CC       pairs of transmembrane channels, the connexons, through which
CC       materials of low MW diffuse from one cell to a neighboring cell.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: A connexon is composed of a hexamer of connexins.
CC       Interacts with SGSM3. Interacts with KIAA1432/CIP150. Interacts
CC       with CNST (By similarity).
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q16643:DBN1 (xeno); NbExp=1; IntAct=EBI-476947, EBI-351394;

CC       Q8VCZ6:Sgsm3 (xeno); NbExp=1; IntAct=EBI-476947, EBI-525155;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC       Cell junction, gap junction.
CC   -!- PTM: Contains at least one intramolecular disulfide bond.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the connexin family. Alpha-type (group II)
CC       subfamily.

RX   PubMed=15947997; DOI=10.1007/s10048-005-0217-4;
RA   Chung K.W., Sunwoo I.N., Kim S.M., Park K.D., Kim W.-K., Kim T.S.,

RL   Neurogenetics 6:159-163(2005).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: One gap junction consists of a cluster of closely packed
CC       pairs of transmembrane channels, the connexons, through which
CC       materials of low MW diffuse from one cell to a neighboring cell.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: A connexon is composed of a hexamer of connexins.
CC       Interacts with CNST (By similarity).
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC       Cell junction, gap junction.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Defects in GJB1 are the cause of Charcot-Marie-Tooth
CC       disease X-linked type 1 (CMTX1) [MIM:302800]; also designated CMT-
CC       X. CMTX1 is a form of Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease, the most common
CC       inherited disorder of the peripheral nervous system. Charcot-
CC       Marie-Tooth disease is classified in two main groups on the basis
CC       of electrophysiologic properties and histopathology: primary
CC       peripheral demyelinating neuropathies characterized by severely
CC       reduced motor nerve conduction velocities (NCVs) (less than 38m/s)
CC       and segmental demyelination and remyelination, and primary
CC       peripheral axonal neuropathies characterized by normal or mildly
CC       reduced NCVs and chronic axonal degeneration and regeneration on
CC       nerve biopsy. CMTX1 has both demyelinating and axonal features.
CC       Central nervous system involvement may occur.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Defects in GJB1 may contribute to the phenotype of
CC       Dejerine-Sottas syndrome (DSS) [MIM:145900]; also known as
CC       Dejerine-Sottas neuropathy (DSN) or hereditary motor and sensory
CC       neuropathy III (HMSN3). DSS is a severe degenerating neuropathy of
CC       the demyelinating Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease category, with onset
CC       by age 2 years. DSS is characterized by motor and sensory
CC       neuropathy with very slow nerve conduction velocities, increased
CC       cerebrospinal fluid protein concentrations, hypertrophic nerve
CC       changes, delayed age of walking as well as areflexia. There are
CC       both autosomal dominant and autosomal recessive forms of Dejerine-
CC       Sottas syndrome.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the connexin family. Beta-type (group I)
CC       subfamily.
CC   -!- WEB RESOURCE: Name=Inherited peripheral neuropathies mutation db;
CC       URL="http://www.molgen.ua.ac.be/CMTMutations/";
CC   -!- WEB RESOURCE: Name=Connexin-deafness homepage;
CC       URL="http://davinci.crg.es/deafness/";
CC   -!- WEB RESOURCE: Name=GeneReviews;
CC       URL="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/sites/GeneTests/lab/gene/GJB1";

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Component of the ubiquinol-cytochrome c reductase
CC       complex (complex III or cytochrome b-c1 complex), which is a
CC       respiratory chain that generates an electrochemical potential
CC       coupled to ATP synthesis (By similarity).
CC   -!- COFACTOR: Binds 2 heme groups non-covalently (By similarity).
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: The main subunits of complex b-c1 are: cytochrome b,
CC       cytochrome c1 and the Rieske protein (By similarity).
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Heme 1 (or BL or b562) is low-potential and absorbs
CC       at about 562 nm, and heme 2 (or BH or b566) is high-potential and
CC       absorbs at about 566 nm (By similarity).
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the cytochrome b family.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Cytochrome d terminal oxidase complex is the component
CC       of the aerobic respiratory chain of E.coli that predominates when
CC       cells are grown at low aeration.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Ubiquinol-8 + O(2) = Ubiquinone-8 + H(2)O.
CC   -!- COFACTOR: Binds 1 protoheme IX group.
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Energy metabolism; oxidative phosphorylation.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterodimer of subunits I and II. Has been isolated from
CC       inner membrane preparations in a complex with one subunit each of
CC       cydB and yhcB, suggesting that yhcB is in fact a subunit of this
CC       complex.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell inner membrane; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the cytochrome ubiquinol oxidase subunit 1
CC       family.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Cytochrome d terminal oxidase complex is the component
CC       of the aerobic respiratory chain of E.coli that predominates when
CC       cells are grown at low aeration.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Ubiquinol-8 + O(2) = Ubiquinone-8 + H(2)O.
CC   -!- COFACTOR: Binds 3 heme groups per dimer. Contains the protoheme IX
CC       center b595 and one iron-chlorin (heme D).
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Energy metabolism; oxidative phosphorylation.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterodimer of subunits I and II. Has been isolated from
CC       inner membrane preparations in a complex with one subunit each of
CC       cydA and yhcB, suggesting that yhcB is in fact a subunit of this
CC       complex.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell inner membrane; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: To E.coli appB.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Cytochrome o terminal oxidase complex is the component
CC       of the aerobic respiratory chain of E.coli that predominates when
CC       cells are grown at high aeration.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Ubiquinol-8 + O(2) = Ubiquinone-8 + H(2)O.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterooctamer of two A chains, two B chains, two C chains
CC       and two D chains.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell inner membrane; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the cytochrome c oxidase subunit 2 family.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Converts heme B (protoheme IX) to heme O by substitution
CC       of the vinyl group on carbon 2 of heme B porphyrin ring with a
CC       hydroxyethyl farnesyl side group.
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Porphyrin metabolism; heme O biosynthesis; heme O from
CC       protoheme: step 1/1.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell inner membrane; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Carbon 2 of the heme B porphyrin ring is defined
CC       according to the Fischer nomenclature.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ubiA prenyltransferase family.
CC       Protoheme IX farnesyltransferase subfamily.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: Member of the two-component regulatory system envZ/ompR
CC       involved in the regulation of osmoregulation (genes ompF and
CC       ompC). EnvZ functions as a membrane-associated protein kinase that
CC       phosphorylates ompR in response to environmental signals.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: ATP + protein L-histidine = ADP + protein N-
CC       phospho-L-histidine.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P0AA16:ompR; NbExp=1; IntAct=EBI-1121750, EBI-369514;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell inner membrane; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The HAMP domain by itself is intrinsically disordered.
CC   -!- PTM: Autophosphorylated.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 HAMP domain.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 histidine kinase domain.

RC   STRAIN=K12;

RA   Abaibou H., Pommier J., Giordano G., Mandrand-Berthelot M.-A.;

RT   a possible physiological role for aerobic formate dehydrogenase.";
RL   J. Bacteriol. 177:7141-7149(1995).

RP   TOPOLOGY.
RX   MEDLINE=99069338; PubMed=9852007;
RA   Benoit S., Abaibou H., Mandrand-Berthelot M.-A.;
RT   "Topological analysis of the aerobic membrane-bound formate
RT   dehydrogenase of Escherichia coli.";
RL   J. Bacteriol. 180:6625-6634(1998).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Allows to use formate as major electron donor during
CC       aerobic respiration. The beta chain is an electron transfer unit
CC       containing 4 cysteine clusters involved in the formation of iron-
CC       sulfur centers. Electrons are transferred from the gamma chain to
CC       the molybdenum cofactor of the alpha subunit (By similarity).
CC   -!- COFACTOR: Binds 4 4Fe-4S clusters per subunit (By similarity).
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Formate dehydrogenase is a membrane-bound complex, formed
CC       by subunits alpha, beta and gamma.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane; Single-pass membrane protein.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 4 4Fe-4S ferredoxin-type domains.

RC   STRAIN=K12 / MG1655 / ATCC 47076;
RX   PubMed=15919996; DOI=10.1126/science.1109730;
RA   Daley D.O., Rapp M., Granseth E., Melen K., Drew D., von Heijne G.;
RT   "Global topology analysis of the Escherichia coli inner membrane
RT   proteome.";
RL   Science 308:1321-1323(2005).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Allows to use formate as major electron donor during
CC       aerobic respiration. Subunit gamma is probably the cytochrome
CC       b556(FDO) component of the formate dehydrogenase.
CC   -!- COFACTOR: Binds 2 heme groups per subunit. Heme 1 is located at
CC       the cytoplasmic interface, heme 2 is located at the periplasmic
CC       interface. Electrons are transferred from the periplasmic to the
CC       cytoplasmic heme (By similarity).
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Formate dehydrogenase is a membrane-bound complex, formed
CC       by subunits alpha, beta and gamma.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell inner membrane; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the formate dehydrogenase gamma subunit
CC       family.

RN   [31]
RP   VARIANT [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS] THR-23.
RX   PubMed=16959974; DOI=10.1126/science.1133427;
RA   Sjoeblom T., Jones S., Wood L.D., Parsons D.W., Lin J., Barber T.D.,
RA   Mandelker D., Leary R.J., Ptak J., Silliman N., Szabo S.,
RA   Buckhaults P., Farrell C., Meeh P., Markowitz S.D., Willis J.,
RA   Dawson D., Willson J.K.V., Gazdar A.F., Hartigan J., Wu L., Liu C.,
RA   Parmigiani G., Park B.H., Bachman K.E., Papadopoulos N.,
RA   Vogelstein B., Kinzler K.W., Velculescu V.E.;
RT   "The consensus coding sequences of human breast and colorectal
RT   cancers.";
RL   Science 314:268-274(2006).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Has both folate hydrolase and N-acetylated-alpha-linked-
CC       acidic dipeptidase (NAALADase) activity. Has a preference for tri-
CC       alpha-glutamate peptides. In the intestine, required for the
CC       uptake of folate. In the brain, modulates excitatory
CC       neurotransmission through the hydrolysis of the neuropeptide, N-
CC       aceylaspartylglutamate (NAAG), thereby releasing glutamate.
CC       Isoform PSM-4 and isoform PSM-5 would appear to be physiologically
CC       irrelevant. Involved in prostate tumor progression.
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Also exhibits a dipeptidyl-peptidase IV type activity.
CC       In vitro, cleaves Gly-Pro-AMC.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Release of an unsubstituted, C-terminal
CC       glutamyl residue, typically from Ac-Asp-Glu or folylpoly-gamma-
CC       glutamates.
CC   -!- COFACTOR: Binds 2 zinc ions per subunit. Required for NAALADase
CC       activity.
CC   -!- ENZYME REGULATION: The NAALADase activity is inhibited by beta-
CC       NAAG, quisqualic acid, 2-(phosphonomethyl) pentanedioic acid
CC       (PMPA) and EDTA. Activated by cobalt.
CC   -!- BIOPHYSICOCHEMICAL PROPERTIES:
CC       pH dependence:
CC         Stable at pH greater than 6.5;
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Homodimer.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell membrane; Single-pass type II membrane
CC       protein.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Isoform PSMA': Cytoplasm.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=8;
CC         Comment=Experimental confirmation may be lacking for some
CC         isoforms;
CC       Name=PSMA-1;
CC         IsoId=Q04609-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=PSMA-2;
CC         IsoId=Q04609-2; Sequence=VSP_005341;
CC       Name=PSMA-3;
CC         IsoId=Q04609-3; Sequence=VSP_005342;
CC       Name=PSMA-4;
CC         IsoId=Q04609-4; Sequence=VSP_005339, VSP_005340;
CC       Name=PSMA-5;
CC         IsoId=Q04609-5; Sequence=VSP_005337, VSP_005338;
CC       Name=PSMA';
CC         IsoId=Q04609-6; Sequence=VSP_005336;
CC       Name=PSMA-7;
CC         IsoId=Q04609-7; Sequence=VSP_038058;
CC       Name=PSMA-8;
CC         IsoId=Q04609-8; Sequence=VSP_038059;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Highly expressed in prostate epithelium.
CC       Detected in urinary bladder, kidney, testis, ovary, fallopian
CC       tube, breast, adrenal gland, liver, esophagus, stomach, small
CC       intestine, colon and brain (at protein level). Detected in the
CC       small intestine, brain, kidney, liver, spleen, colon, trachea,
CC       spinal cord and the capillary endothelium of a variety of tumors.
CC       Expressed specifically in jejunum brush border membranes. In the
CC       brain, highly expressed in the ventral striatum and brain stem.
CC       Also expressed in fetal liver and kidney. In the prostate, the
CC       PSMA' cytosolic isoform is the most abundant form in normal
CC       tissue, the membrane-bound PSMA-1 form in primary prostate tumors.
CC       Isoform PSMA-2 is also found in normal prostate as well as in
CC       brain and liver.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: In the prostate, up-regulated in response to androgen
CC       deprivation.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The NAALADase activity is found in the central region, the
CC       dipeptidyl peptidase IV type activity in the C-terminal.
CC   -!- PTM: The first two amino acids at the N-terminus of isoform PSMA'
CC       appear to be cleaved by limited proteolysis.
CC   -!- PTM: The N-terminus is blocked.
CC   -!- POLYMORPHISM: Genetic variation in FOLH1 may be associated with
CC       low folate levels and consequent hyperhomocysteinemia. This
CC       condition can result in increased risk of cardiovascular disease,
CC       neural tube defects, and cognitive deficits.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: PSMA is used as a diagnostic and prognostic
CC       indicator of prostate cancer, and as a possible marker for various
CC       neurological disorders such as schizophrenia, Alzheimer disease
CC       and Huntington disease.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the peptidase M28 family. M28B subfamily.
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License
CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

RP   TOPOLOGY.
RX   MEDLINE=99287588; PubMed=10360843; DOI=10.1089/104454999315312;
RA   Goo J.H., Ahn Y., Park W.J.;
RT   "Frizzled-suc2 fusion gene studies in Saccharomyces cerevisiae.";
RL   DNA Cell Biol. 18:429-434(1999).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Receptor for Wnt proteins. Most of frizzled receptors
CC       are coupled to the beta-catenin canonical signaling pathway, which
CC       leads to the activation of disheveled proteins, inhibition of GSK-
CC       3 kinase, nuclear accumulation of beta-catenin and activation of
CC       Wnt target genes. A second signaling pathway involving PKC and
CC       calcium fluxes has been seen for some family members, but it is
CC       not yet clear if it represents a distinct pathway or if it can be
CC       integrated in the canonical pathway, as PKC seems to be required
CC       for Wnt-mediated inactivation of GSK-3 kinase. Both pathways seem
CC       to involve interactions with G-proteins. Required to coordinate
CC       the cytoskeletons of epidermal cells to produce a parallel array
CC       of cuticular hairs and bristles.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       Q9VUI0:gnu; NbExp=1; IntAct=EBI-251599, EBI-174199;
CC       Q9V5N8:stan; NbExp=3; IntAct=EBI-251576, EBI-119250;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=I;
CC         IsoId=P18537-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=II;
CC         IsoId=P18537-2; Sequence=VSP_002013, VSP_002014;
CC   -!- DOMAIN: Lys-Thr-X-X-X-Trp motif is involved in the activation of
CC       the Wnt/beta-catenin signaling pathway (By similarity).
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The FZ domain is involved in binding with Wnt ligands (By
CC       similarity).
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the G-protein coupled receptor Fz/Smo
CC       family.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 FZ (frizzled) domain.

RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (1.5 ANGSTROMS) OF 141-397.
RX   MEDLINE=22032483; PubMed=12037319; DOI=10.1107/S0907444902006972;
RA   Krzywda S., Brzozowski A.M., Karata K., Ogura T., Wilkinson A.J.;
RT   "Crystallization of the AAA domain of the ATP-dependent protease FtsH
RT   of Escherichia coli.";
RL   Acta Crystallogr. D 582:1066-1067(2002).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Seems to act as an ATP-dependent zinc metallopeptidase.
CC       Involved in the degradation of sigma-32. Degrades C-terminal-
CC       tagged cytoplasmic proteins. These proteins are tagged with an 11-
CC       amino-acid nonpolar destabilizing tail via a mechanism involving
CC       the 10SA (ssrA) stable RNA.
CC   -!- COFACTOR: Binds 1 zinc ion per subunit (Potential).
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P05719:hsdS; NbExp=1; IntAct=EBI-548381, EBI-1135164;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell inner membrane; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: In the N-terminal section; belongs to the AAA ATPase
CC       family.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: In the C-terminal section; belongs to the peptidase
CC       M41 family.

RP   TOPOLOGY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RC   STRAIN=K12 / MG1655 / ATCC 47076;
RX   PubMed=15919996; DOI=10.1126/science.1109730;
RA   Daley D.O., Rapp M., Granseth E., Melen K., Drew D., von Heijne G.;
RT   "Global topology analysis of the Escherichia coli inner membrane
RT   proteome.";
RL   Science 308:1321-1323(2005).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Mediates the uptake of L-fucose across the boundary
CC       membrane with the concomitant transport of protons into the cell
CC       (symport system). Can also transport L-galactose and D-arabinose,
CC       but at reduced rates compared with L-fucose. Is not able to
CC       transport L-rhamnose and L-arabinose.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell inner membrane; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: By L-fucose.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the major facilitator superfamily. FHS
CC       transporter (TC 2.A.1.7) family.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: GABA, the major inhibitory neurotransmitter in the
CC       vertebrate brain, mediates neuronal inhibition by binding to the
CC       GABA/benzodiazepine receptor and opening an integral chloride
CC       channel.

CC       (By similarity).

CC       membrane protein.

CC       stellate/basket cells.

RP   INVOLVEMENT IN ECA4.
RX   PubMed=16718694; DOI=10.1002/ana.20874;
RA   Maljevic S., Krampfl K., Cobilanschi J., Tilgen N., Beyer S.,
RA   Weber Y.G., Schlesinger F., Ursu D., Melzer W., Cossette P.,
RA   Bufler J., Lerche H., Heils A.;
RT   "A mutation in the GABA(A) receptor alpha(1)-subunit is associated
RT   with absence epilepsy.";
RL   Ann. Neurol. 59:983-987(2006).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: GABA, the major inhibitory neurotransmitter in the
CC       vertebrate brain, mediates neuronal inhibition by binding to the
CC       GABA/benzodiazepine receptor and opening an integral chloride
CC       channel.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Binds UBQLN1 (By similarity). Generally pentameric. There
CC       are five types of GABA(A) receptor chains: alpha, beta, gamma,
CC       delta, and rho.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein. Cell membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Defects in GABRA1 are a cause of juvenile myoclonic
CC       epilepsy (EJM) [MIM:606904]. EJM is a subtype of idiopathic
CC       generalized epilepsy. Patients have afebrile seizures only, with
CC       onset in adolescence (rather than in childhood) and myoclonic
CC       jerks which usually occur after awakening and are triggered by
CC       sleep deprivation and fatigue.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Defects in GABRA1 are the cause of childhood absence
CC       epilepsy type 4 (ECA4) [MIM:611136]. ECA4 is a subtype of
CC       idiopathic generalized epilepsy (IGE) characterized by onset at
CC       age 6-7 years, frequent absence seizures (several per day) and
CC       bilateral, synchronous, symmetric 3-Hz spike waves on EEG. During
CC       adolescence, tonic-clonic and myoclonic seizures develop. Absence
CC       seizures may either remit or persist into adulthood.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ionic channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family.
CC   -!- WEB RESOURCE: Name=Protein Spotlight; Note=Forbidden fruit - Issue
CC       56 of March 2005;
CC       URL="http://www.expasy.org/spotlight/back_issues/sptlt056.shtml";

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License

CC   -!- FUNCTION: GABA, the major inhibitory neurotransmitter in the
CC       vertebrate brain, mediates neuronal inhibition by binding to the
CC       GABA/benzodiazepine receptor and opening an integral chloride
CC       channel.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Generally pentameric. There are five types of GABA(A)

CC   -!- FUNCTION: GABA, the major inhibitory neurotransmitter in the
CC       vertebrate brain, mediates neuronal inhibition by binding to the
CC       GABA/benzodiazepine receptor and opening an integral chloride
CC       channel.

RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [LARGE SCALE MRNA].
RC   TISSUE=Brain;
RX   PubMed=15489334; DOI=10.1101/gr.2596504;

RT   "The status, quality, and expansion of the NIH full-length cDNA
RT   project: the Mammalian Gene Collection (MGC).";
RL   Genome Res. 14:2121-2127(2004).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: GABA, the major inhibitory neurotransmitter in the
CC       vertebrate brain, mediates neuronal inhibition by binding to the
CC       GABA/benzodiazepine receptor and opening an integral chloride
CC       channel.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Binds UBQLN1 (By similarity). Generally pentameric. There
CC       are five types of GABA(A) receptor chains: alpha, beta, gamma,
CC       delta, and rho.
CC   -!- INTERACTION:
CC       P27986:PIK3R1; NbExp=1; IntAct=EBI-1763805, EBI-79464;
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein. Cell membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ionic channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family.

CC       56 of March 2005;

CC   -!- FUNCTION: GABA, the major inhibitory neurotransmitter in the
CC       vertebrate brain, mediates neuronal inhibition by binding to the
CC       GABA/benzodiazepine receptor and opening an integral chloride
CC       channel.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Generally pentameric. There are five types of GABA(A)
CC       receptor chains: alpha, beta, gamma, delta, and rho.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein. Cell membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein.
CC   -!- INDUCTION: The alpha4 beta2 gamma 2L receptor is not repressed by
CC       diazepam.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ionic channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: GABA, the major inhibitory neurotransmitter in the
CC       vertebrate brain, mediates neuronal inhibition by binding to the
CC       GABA/benzodiazepine receptor and opening an integral chloride
CC       channel.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Binds UBQLN1 (By similarity). Generally pentameric. There
CC       are five types of GABA(A) receptor chains: alpha, beta, gamma,
CC       delta, and rho.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein. Cell membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ionic channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: GABA, the major inhibitory neurotransmitter in the
CC       vertebrate brain, mediates neuronal inhibition by binding to the
CC       GABA/benzodiazepine receptor and opening an integral chloride
CC       channel.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Generally pentameric. There are five types of GABA(A)
CC       receptor chains: alpha, beta, gamma, delta, and rho. Binds UBQLN1.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein. Cell membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein.

RX   PubMed=18514161; DOI=10.1016/j.ajhg.2008.04.020;
RA   Tanaka M., Olsen R.W., Medina M.T., Schwartz E., Alonso M.E.,
RA   Duron R.M., Castro-Ortega R., Martinez-Juarez I.E.,
RA   Pascual-Castroviejo I., Machado-Salas J., Silva R., Bailey J.N.,
RA   Bai D., Ochoa A., Jara-Prado A., Pineda G., Macdonald R.L.,
RA   Delgado-Escueta A.V.;
RT   "Hyperglycosylation and reduced GABA currents of mutated GABRB3
RT   polypeptide in remitting childhood absence epilepsy.";
RL   Am. J. Hum. Genet. 82:1249-1261(2008).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: GABA, the major inhibitory neurotransmitter in the
CC       vertebrate brain, mediates neuronal inhibition by binding to the
CC       GABA/benzodiazepine receptor and opening an integral chloride
CC       channel.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Binds UBQLN1 (By similarity). Generally pentameric. There
CC       are five types of GABA(A) receptor chains: alpha, beta, gamma,
CC       delta, and rho.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein. Cell membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC         Comment=Isoforms differ in their signal region;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=P28472-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=P28472-2; Sequence=VSP_000088;
CC         Note=Variant in position: 11:P->S (in ECA5, the mutant protein
CC         is hyperglycosylated and has reduced mean current densities
CC         compared to wild-type, dbSNP:rs25409). Variant in position:
CC         15:S->F (in ECA5, the mutant protein is hyperglycosylated and
CC         has reduced mean current densities compared to wild-type);
CC   -!- DISEASE: Defects in GABRB3 are a cause of chonic insomnia.
CC       Insomnia is characterized by impairment of the ability to initiate
CC       or maintain sleep. This may occur as a primary disorder or in
CC       association with another medical or psychiatric condition.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Defects in GABRB3 are the cause of childhood absence
CC       epilepsy type 5 (ECA5) [MIM:612269]. ECA5 is a subtype of
CC       idiopathic generalized epilepsy (IGE) characterized by an onset at
CC       age 6-7 years, frequent absence seizures (several per day) and
CC       bilateral, synchronous, symmetric 3-Hz spike waves on EEG. During
CC       adolescence, tonic-clonic and myoclonic seizures develop. Absence
CC       seizures may either remit or persist into adulthood.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ionic channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family.
CC   -!- WEB RESOURCE: Name=Protein Spotlight; Note=Forbidden fruit - Issue
CC       56 of March 2005;
CC       URL="http://www.expasy.org/spotlight/back_issues/sptlt056.shtml";

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License

RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [LARGE SCALE MRNA].
RC   TISSUE=Brain;
RX   PubMed=15489334; DOI=10.1101/gr.2596504;

RN   [4]
RP   VARIANT GEFS+5 ALA-177, VARIANTS CYS-220 AND HIS-220, CHARACTERIZATION
RP   OF VARIANT GEFS+5 ALA-177, AND CHARACTERIZATION OF VARIANTS CYS-220
RP   AND HIS-220.
RX   PubMed=15115768; DOI=10.1093/hmg/ddh146;
RA   Dibbens L.M., Feng H.-J., Richards M.C., Harkin L.A., Hodgson B.L.,
RA   Scott D., Jenkins M., Petrou S., Sutherland G.R., Scheffer I.E.,
RA   Berkovic S.F., Macdonald R.L., Mulley J.C.;
RT   "GABRD encoding a protein for extra- or peri-synaptic GABAA receptors
RT   is a susceptibility locus for generalized epilepsies.";
RL   Hum. Mol. Genet. 13:1315-1319(2004).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: GABA, the major inhibitory neurotransmitter in the
CC       vertebrate brain, mediates neuronal inhibition by binding to the
CC       GABA/benzodiazepine receptor and opening an integral chloride
CC       channel.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Generally pentameric. There are five types of GABA(A)
CC       receptor chains: alpha, beta, gamma, delta, and rho.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein. Cell membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Defects in GABRD are the cause of susceptibility to
CC       generalized epilepsy with febrile seizures plus type 5 (GEFS+5)
CC       [MIM:604233]. Generalized epilepsy with febrile seizures-plus
CC       refers to a rare familial condition with incomplete penetrance and
CC       large intrafamilial variability. Patients display febrile seizures
CC       persisting sometimes beyond the age of 6 years and/or a variety of
CC       afebrile seizure types. GEFS+ is a disease combining febrile
CC       seizures, generalized seizures often precipitated by fever at age
CC       6 years or more, and partial seizures, with a variable degree of
CC       severity.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Defects in GABRD are the cause of susceptibility to
CC       idiopathic generalized epilepsy type 10 (IGE10) [MIM:613060]. A
CC       disorder characterized by recurring generalized seizures in the
CC       absence of detectable brain lesions and/or metabolic
CC       abnormalities. Generalized seizures arise diffusely and
CC       simultaneously from both hemispheres of the brain.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Defects in GABRD are the cause of susceptibility to
CC       juvenile myoclonic epilepsy type 7 (EJM7) [MIM:613060]. A subtype
CC       of idiopathic generalized epilepsy. Patients have afebrile
CC       seizures only, with onset in adolescence (rather than in
CC       childhood) and myoclonic jerks which usually occur after awakening
CC       and are triggered by sleep deprivation and fatigue.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ionic channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family.

RX   MEDLINE=21225285; PubMed=11326275; DOI=10.1038/88259;
RA   Wallace R.H., Marini C., Petrou S., Harkin L.A., Bowser D.N.,

RN   [8]
RP   VARIANT FEB8 GLY-177.
RX   PubMed=16924025; DOI=10.1212/01.wnl.0000230145.73496.a2;
RA   Audenaert D., Schwartz E., Claeys K.G., Claes L., Deprez L., Suls A.,
RA   Van Dyck T., Lagae L., Van Broeckhoven C., Macdonald R.L.,
RA   De Jonghe P.;
RT   "A novel GABRG2 mutation associated with febrile seizures.";
RL   Neurology 67:687-690(2006).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: GABA, the major inhibitory neurotransmitter in the
CC       vertebrate brain, mediates neuronal inhibition by binding to the
CC       GABA/benzodiazepine receptor and opening an integral chloride
CC       channel.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Generally pentameric. There are five types of GABA(A)
CC       receptor chains: alpha, beta, gamma, delta, and rho. Interacts
CC       with GABARAP.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein. Cell membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein.
CC   -!- PTM: Palmitoylated by ZDHHC3/GODZ; which may affect presynaptic
CC       clustering and/or cell surface stability (By similarity).
CC   -!- DISEASE: Defects in GABRG2 are the cause of childhood absence
CC       epilepsy type 2 (ECA2) [MIM:607681]. ECA2 is a subtype of
CC       idiopathic generalized epilepsy (IGE) characterized by an onset at
CC       age 6-7 years, frequent absence seizures (several per day) and
CC       bilateral, synchronous, symmetric 3-Hz spike waves on EEG. During
CC       adolescence, tonic-clonic and myoclonic seizures develop. Some
CC       individuals manifest ECA2 occurring in combination with febrile
CC       convulsions [MIM:611277].
CC   -!- DISEASE: Defects in GABRG2 are the cause of familial febrile
CC       convulsions type 8 (FEB8) [MIM:611277]. A febrile convulsion is
CC       defined as a seizure event in infancy or childhood, usually
CC       occurring between 6 months and 6 years of age, associated with
CC       fever but without any evidence of intracranial infection or
CC       defined pathologic or traumatic cause. Febrile convulsions affect
CC       5-12% of infants and children up to 6 years of age. There is
CC       epidemiological evidence that febrile seizures are associated with
CC       subsequent afebrile and unprovoked seizures in 2% to 7% of
CC       patients.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Defects in GABRG2 are the cause of generalized epilepsy
CC       with febrile seizures plus type 3 (GEFS+3) [MIM:604233].
CC       Generalized epilepsy with febrile seizures-plus refers to a rare
CC       autosomal dominant, familial condition with incomplete penetrance
CC       and large intrafamilial variability. Patients display febrile
CC       seizures persisting sometimes beyond the age of 6 years and/or a
CC       variety of afebrile seizure types. GEFS+ is a disease combining
CC       febrile seizures, generalized seizures often precipitated by fever
CC       at age 6 years or more, and partial seizures, with a variable
CC       degree of severity.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Defects in GABRG2 are a cause of severe myoclonic
CC       epilepsy in infancy (SMEI) [MIM:607208]; also called Dravet
CC       syndrome. SMEI is a rare disorder characterized by generalized
CC       tonic, clonic, and tonic-clonic seizures that are initially
CC       induced by fever and begin during the first year of life. Later,
CC       patients also manifest other seizure types, including absence,
CC       myoclonic, and simple and complex partial seizures. Psychomotor
CC       development delay is observed around the second year of life. SMEI
CC       is considered to be the most severe phenotype within the spectrum
CC       of generalized epilepsies with febrile seizures-plus.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: This subunit carries the benzodiazepine binding
CC       site.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ionic channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family.
CC   -!- WEB RESOURCE: Name=Protein Spotlight; Note=Forbidden fruit - Issue
CC       56 of March 2005;
CC       URL="http://www.expasy.org/spotlight/back_issues/sptlt056.shtml";

CC   -!- FUNCTION: GABA, the major inhibitory neurotransmitter in the
CC       vertebrate brain, mediates neuronal inhibition by binding to the
CC       GABA/benzodiazepine receptor and opening an integral chloride
CC       channel.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Generally pentameric. There are five types of GABA(A)
CC       receptor chains: alpha, beta, gamma, delta, and rho.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein. Cell membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=2L;
CC         IsoId=P22723-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=2S;
CC         IsoId=P22723-2; Sequence=VSP_000091;
CC   -!- PTM: Palmitoylated by ZDHHC3/GODZ; which may affect presynaptic
CC       clustering and/or cell surface stability.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: This subunit carries the benzodiazepine binding
CC       site.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ionic channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family.

RP   INTERACTION WITH SQSTM1.
RX   MEDLINE=22476897; PubMed=12431995; DOI=10.1074/jbc.M205162200;
RA   Croci C., Brandstaetter J.H., Enz R.;
RT   "ZIP3, a new splice variant of the PKC-zeta-interacting protein
RT   family, binds to GABAC receptors, PKC-zeta, and Kv beta 2.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 278:6128-6135(2003).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: GABA, the major inhibitory neurotransmitter in the
CC       vertebrate brain, mediates neuronal inhibition by binding to the
CC       GABA/benzodiazepine receptor and opening an integral chloride
CC       channel. Rho-1 GABA receptor could play a role in retinal
CC       neurotransmission.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Generally pentameric. There are five types of GABA(A)
CC       receptor chains: alpha, beta, gamma, delta, and rho. Interacts
CC       with SQSTM1.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein. Cell membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ionic channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family.

CC       vertebrate brain, mediates neuronal inhibition by binding to the

CC       channel.

RP   GLYCOSYLATION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS] AT ASN-120; ASN-230 AND ASN-511,
RP   AND MASS SPECTROMETRY.
RC   TISSUE=Liver;
RX   PubMed=19159218; DOI=10.1021/pr8008012;
RA   Chen R., Jiang X., Sun D., Han G., Wang F., Ye M., Wang L., Zou H.;

RN   [21]
RP   GLYCOSYLATION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS] AT ASN-120, AND MASS
RP   SPECTROMETRY.
RX   PubMed=19349973; DOI=10.1038/nbt.1532;
RA   Wollscheid B., Bausch-Fluck D., Henderson C., O'Brien R., Bibel M.,
RA   Schiess R., Aebersold R., Watts J.D.;
RT   "Mass-spectrometric identification and relative quantification of N-
RT   linked cell surface glycoproteins.";
RL   Nat. Biotechnol. 27:378-386(2009).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Initiates extracellular glutathione (GSH) breakdown,
CC       provides cells with a local cysteine supply and contributes to
CC       maintain intracelular GSH level. It is part of the cell
CC       antioxidant defense mechanism. Catalyzes the transfer of the
CC       glutamyl moiety of glutathione to amino acids and dipeptide
CC       acceptors. Alternatively, glutathione can be hydrolyzed to give
CC       Cys-Gly and gamma glutamate. Isoform 3 seems to be inactive.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: (5-L-glutamyl)-peptide + an amino acid =
CC       peptide + 5-L-glutamyl amino acid.
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Sulfur metabolism; glutathione metabolism.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterodimer composed of the light and heavy chains. The
CC       active site is located in the light chain.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane; Single-pass type II membrane
CC       protein.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative promoter usage, Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=3;
CC       Name=1;
CC         IsoId=P19440-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC         Note=Produced by alternative promoter usage;
CC       Name=2;
CC         IsoId=P19440-2; Sequence=VSP_001746, VSP_001747;
CC         Note=Produced by alternative splicing of isoform 1;
CC       Name=3;
CC         IsoId=P19440-3; Sequence=VSP_008132;
CC         Note=Produced by alternative promoter usage;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Detected in fetal and adult kidney and liver,
CC       adult pancreas, stomach, intestine, placenta and lung. Isoform 3
CC       is lung-specific. There are several other tissue-specific forms
CC       that arise from alternative promoter usage but that produce the
CC       same protein.
CC   -!- PTM: N-glycosylated on both chains. Contains hexoses, hexosamines
CC       and sialic acid residues. It is not known if the sialic acid
CC       residues are present on N-linked or on O-linked glycans.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Defects in GGT1 are a cause of glutathionuria
CC       [MIM:231950]; also known as gamma-glutamyltranspeptidase
CC       deficiency. It is an autosomal recessive disease.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Cys-454 was thought to bind the gamma-glutamyl
CC       moiety, but mutagenesis of this residue had no effect on activity.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the gamma-glutamyltransferase family.
CC   -!- WEB RESOURCE: Name=Wikipedia; Note=Gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase
CC       entry;
CC       URL="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gamma_glutamyl_transpeptidase";

CC   -----------------------------------------------------------------------

RP   DISEASE.
RX   MEDLINE=97284731; PubMed=9139708; DOI=10.1074/jbc.272.19.12560;
RA   Harding C.O., Williams P., Wagner E., Chang D.S., Wild K.,
RA   Colwell R.E., Wolff J.A.;
RT   "Mice with genetic gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase deficiency exhibit
RT   glutathionuria, severe growth failure, reduced life spans, and
RT   infertility.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 272:12560-12567(1997).
RN   [5]
RP   DISEASE, AND FUNCTION.
RX   MEDLINE=22694588; PubMed=12810527; DOI=10.1210/en.2002-0071;
RA   Levasseur R., Barrios R., Elefteriou F., Glass D.A. II,
RA   Lieberman M.W., Karsenty G.;
RT   "Reversible skeletal abnormalities in gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase-
RT   deficient mice.";
RL   Endocrinology 144:2761-2764(2003).
RN   [6]
RP   GLYCOSYLATION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS] AT ASN-114; ASN-120; ASN-229 AND
RP   ASN-510, AND MASS SPECTROMETRY.
RX   PubMed=19349973; DOI=10.1038/nbt.1532;
RA   Wollscheid B., Bausch-Fluck D., Henderson C., O'Brien R., Bibel M.,
RA   Schiess R., Aebersold R., Watts J.D.;
RT   "Mass-spectrometric identification and relative quantification of N-
RT   linked cell surface glycoproteins.";
RL   Nat. Biotechnol. 27:378-386(2009).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Initiates extracellular glutathione (GSH) breakdown,
CC       provides cells with a local cysteine supply and contributes to
CC       maintain intracelular GSH level. It is part of the cell
CC       antioxidant defense mechanism. Catalyzes the transfer of the
CC       glutamyl moiety of glutathione to amino acids and dipeptide
CC       acceptors. Alternatively, glutathione can be hydrolyzed to give
CC       Cys-Gly and gamma glutamate. Indirectly regulates mutiple aspects
CC       of skeletal biology.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: (5-L-glutamyl)-peptide + an amino acid =
CC       peptide + 5-L-glutamyl amino acid.
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Sulfur metabolism; glutathione metabolism.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterodimer composed of the light and heavy chains. The
CC       active site is located in the light chain (By similarity).
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane; Single-pass type II membrane
CC       protein (By similarity).
CC   -!- DISEASE: Defects in Ggt1 are a cause of glutathionuria, severe
CC       growth failure, reduced life spans and infertility. Ggt1-deficient
CC       mice have multiple metabolic abnormalities and are dwarf. Some
CC       abnormalities can be ameliorated by N-acetylcysteine treatment.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the gamma-glutamyltransferase family.

RN   [14]
RP   GLYCOSYLATION.
RX   MEDLINE=90062217; PubMed=2573604;
RA   Blochberger T.C., Sabatine J.M., Lee Y.C., Hughey R.P.;
RT   "O-linked glycosylation of rat renal gamma-glutamyltranspeptidase
RT   adjacent to its membrane anchor domain.";
RL   J. Biol. Chem. 264:20718-20722(1989).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Initiates extracellular glutathione (GSH) breakdown,
CC       provides cells with a local cysteine supply and contributes to
CC       maintain intracelular GSH level. It is part of the cell
CC       antioxidant defense mechanism. Catalyzes the transfer of the
CC       glutamyl moiety of glutathione to amino acids and dipeptide
CC       acceptors. Alternatively, glutathione can be hydrolyzed to give
CC       Cys-Gly and gamma glutamate.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: (5-L-glutamyl)-peptide + an amino acid =
CC       peptide + 5-L-glutamyl amino acid.
CC   -!- PATHWAY: Sulfur metabolism; glutathione metabolism.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Heterodimer composed of the light and heavy chains. The
CC       active site is located in the light chain.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Membrane; Single-pass type II membrane
CC       protein.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Detected in adult kidney and mammary gland,
CC       and in fetal liver.
CC   -!- PTM: N-glycosylated on both chains; contains sialic acid residues.
CC       It is not known if the sialic acid residues are present on N-
CC       linked or on O-linked glycans.
CC   -!- PTM: O-glycosylated; close to the membrane anchor on the heavy
CC       chain and on the light chain. The sugar moieties are localized to
CC       the stretch Thr-28 to Ser-30. Contains sialic acid residues. It is
CC       not known if the sialic acid residues are present on N-linked or
CC       on O-linked glycans.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the gamma-glutamyltransferase family.
CC   -!- SEQUENCE CAUTION:
CC       Sequence=CAA27224.1; Type=Frameshift; Positions=66, 134;

RN   [13]
RP   X-RAY CRYSTALLOGRAPHY (2.5 ANGSTROMS) OF 93-272, AND ACTIVE SITE.
RX   PubMed=17277078; DOI=10.1073/pnas.0611080104;
RA   Wang Y., Ha Y.;
RT   "Open-cap conformation of intramembrane protease GlpG.";
RL   Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 104:2098-2102(2007).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Rhomboid-type serine protease that catalyzes
CC       intramembrane proteolysis.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Cleaves type-1 transmembrane domains using a
CC       catalytic dyad composed of serine and histidine that are
CC       contributed by different transmembrane domains.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell inner membrane; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The loop between transmembrane domains 5 and 6 is flexible
CC       and may readily open to the extracellular side to allow water
CC       entry into the active site cavity.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the peptidase S54 family.
CC   -!- CAUTION: Was originally (PubMed:8955387) identified as a repressor
CC       of the glycerol-3-phosphate regulon.

RP   VARIANT STHE THR-278.
RX   MEDLINE=99119431; PubMed=9920650;
RA   Saul B., Kuner T., Sobetzko D., Brune W., Hanefeld F., Meinck H.-M.,

RT   gating.";
RL   J. Neurosci. 19:869-877(1999).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: The glycine receptor is a neurotransmitter-gated ion
CC       channel. Binding of glycine to its receptor increases the chloride
CC       conductance and thus produces hyperpolarization (inhibition of
CC       neuronal firing).
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Pentamer composed of alpha and beta subunits.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein. Cell membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=a;
CC         IsoId=P23415-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=b;
CC         IsoId=P23415-2; Sequence=VSP_021142;
CC   -!- DISEASE: Defects in GLRA1 are a cause of startle disease (STHE)
CC       [MIM:149400]; also known as hereditary hyperekplexia or congenital
CC       stiff-person syndrome. STHE is a genetically heterogeneous
CC       neurologic disorder characterized by muscular rigidity of central
CC       nervous system origin, particularly in the neonatal period, and by
CC       an exaggerated startle response to unexpected acoustic or tactile
CC       stimuli. Inheritance can be autosomal dominant or recessive.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: The alpha subunit binds strychnine.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ionic channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family.
CC   -!- WEB RESOURCE: Name=GeneReviews;
CC       URL="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/sites/GeneTests/lab/gene/GLRA1";

CC   -!- FUNCTION: The glycine receptor is a neurotransmitter-gated ion
CC       channel. Binding of glycine to its receptor increases the chloride
CC       conductance and thus produces hyperpolarization (inhibition of
CC       neuronal firing).
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Pentamer composed of alpha and beta subunits.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein. Cell membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=a; Synonyms=Long;
CC         IsoId=Q64018-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=b; Synonyms=Short;
CC         IsoId=Q64018-2; Sequence=VSP_000080;
CC   -!- DISEASE: Defects in Glra1 are the cause of the spasmodic (spd)
CC       phenotype, a mouse mutant which resembles to the human
CC       neurological disease, hyperekplexia (or startle disease (STHE)).
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: The alpha subunit binds strychnine.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ionic channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family.

RX   MEDLINE=91027731; PubMed=2171639; DOI=10.1021/bi00482a012;

RT   "Localization of the strychnine binding site on the 48-kilodalton
RT   subunit of the glycine receptor.";
RL   Biochemistry 29:7033-7040(1990).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: The glycine receptor is a neurotransmitter-gated ion
CC       channel. Binding of glycine to its receptor increases the chloride
CC       conductance and thus produces hyperpolarization (inhibition of
CC       neuronal firing).
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Pentamer composed of alpha and beta subunits.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein. Cell membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein.

CC         IsoId=P07727-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=b; Synonyms=Short;
CC         IsoId=P07727-2; Sequence=VSP_000081;
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: The alpha subunit binds strychnine.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ionic channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family.

RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [MRNA].
RC   TISSUE=Brain;
RX   MEDLINE=91243883; PubMed=1645300; DOI=10.1016/0014-5793(91)80557-J;
RA   Kuhse J., Kuryatov A., Maulet Y., Malosio M.L., Schmieden V., Betz H.;

RP   NUCLEOTIDE SEQUENCE [MRNA].
RC   STRAIN=Sprague-Dawley; TISSUE=Brain;
RA   Beato M., Groot Kormelink P.J., Colquhoun D., Sivilotti L.G.;
RT   "Concentration dependence of single channel currents through rat
RT   recombinant alpha 1 glycine receptors.";
RL   Submitted (MAR-2001) to the EMBL/GenBank/DDBJ databases.
CC   -!- FUNCTION: The glycine receptor is a neurotransmitter-gated ion
CC       channel. Binding of glycine to its receptor increases the chloride
CC       conductance and thus produces hyperpolarization (inhibition of
CC       neuronal firing).
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Pentamer composed of alpha and beta subunits.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein. Cell membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=Alpha-2*;
CC         IsoId=P22771-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=Alpha-2B;
CC         IsoId=P22771-2; Sequence=VSP_000083;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: The glycine receptor is abundant in the spinal
CC       cord and brainstem of vertebrates.
CC   -!- DEVELOPMENTAL STAGE: The alpha-2* subunit isoform is present only
CC       in neonatal rats. Isoforms alpha-2a and alpha-2b are present in
CC       the pre- and neonatal brain. At later postnatal stages, alpha-2a
CC       levels greatly decrease while alpha-2b is barely detectable.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: The alpha subunit binds strychnine.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: Identical to the human subunit alpha-2, except for
CC       5 substitutions at positions 18, 24, 37, 194 and 404. Substitution
CC       at position 194 (G -> E) accounts for the lower strychnine
CC       sensitivity observed in neonatal rats.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ionic channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family.

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License

RP   PHOSPHORYLATION [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS] AT SER-382, AND MASS
RP   SPECTROMETRY.
RX   PubMed=18187866; DOI=10.2116/analsci.24.161;
RA   Imami K., Sugiyama N., Kyono Y., Tomita M., Ishihama Y.;

RT   dimensional nanoLC-MS using a calcined titania/C18 biphasic column.";

CC   -!- FUNCTION: The glycine receptor is a neurotransmitter-gated ion
CC       channel. Binding of glycine to its receptor increases the chloride
CC       conductance and thus produces hyperpolarization (inhibition of
CC       neuronal firing).
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Pentamer composed of alpha and beta subunits (By
CC       similarity).
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein. Cell membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein.
CC   -!- ALTERNATIVE PRODUCTS:
CC       Event=Alternative splicing; Named isoforms=2;
CC       Name=Alpha-3L;
CC         IsoId=O75311-1; Sequence=Displayed;
CC       Name=Alpha-3K;
CC         IsoId=O75311-2; Sequence=VSP_000084;
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: Widely distributed throughout the central
CC       nervous system.
CC   -!- DOMAIN: The N-terminal domain carries structural determinants
CC       essential for agonist and antagonist binding. TM2 is thought to
CC       form the innert wall of the chloride channel. The cytoplasmic loop
CC       is an important determinant of channel inactivation kinetics.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: The alpha subunit binds strychnine.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ionic channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family.

RP   VARIANT STHE ASP-251.
RX   PubMed=11929858; DOI=10.1093/hmg/11.7.853;
RA   Rees M.I., Lewis T.M., Kwok J.B.J., Mortier G.R., Govaert P.,
RA   Snell R.G., Schofield P.R., Owen M.J.;
RT   "Hyperekplexia associated with compound heterozygote mutations in the
RT   beta-subunit of the human inhibitory glycine receptor (GLRB).";
RL   Hum. Mol. Genet. 11:853-860(2002).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: The glycine receptor is a neurotransmitter-gated ion
CC       channel. Binding of glycine to its receptor increases the chloride
CC       conductance and thus produces hyperpolarization (inhibition of
CC       neuronal firing).
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Pentamer composed of alpha and beta subunits. Interacts
CC       with GPHN (By similarity).
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein. Cell membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Defects in GLRB are a cause of startle disease (STHE)
CC       [MIM:149400]; also known as hereditary hyperekplexia or congenital
CC       stiff-person syndrome. STHE is a genetically heterogeneous
CC       neurologic disorder characterized by muscular rigidity of central
CC       nervous system origin, particularly in the neonatal period, and by
CC       an exaggerated startle response to unexpected acoustic or tactile
CC       stimuli. Inheritance can be autosomal dominant or recessive.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ionic channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family.
CC   -!- WEB RESOURCE: Name=GeneReviews;
CC       URL="http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/sites/GeneTests/lab/gene/GLRB";

CC   -!- FUNCTION: The glycine receptor is a neurotransmitter-gated ion
CC       channel. Binding of glycine to its receptor increases the chloride
CC       conductance and thus produces hyperpolarization (inhibition of
CC       neuronal firing).
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Pentamer composed of alpha and beta subunits. Interacts
CC       with GPHN (By similarity).
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein. Cell membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein.
CC   -!- TISSUE SPECIFICITY: High levels of expression in cortex,
CC       hippocampus, thalamus and cerebellum.
CC   -!- DISEASE: Defects in Glrb cause the spastic condition which is
CC       characterized by muscle rigidity, tremors, myoclonic jerks,
CC       pronounced startle reaction, abnormal gait and impaired righting
CC       ability.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ionic channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family.

CC   -!- FUNCTION: The glycine receptor is a neurotransmitter-gated ion
CC       channel. Binding of glycine to its receptor increases the chloride
CC       conductance and thus produces hyperpolarization (inhibition of
CC       neuronal firing).
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: Pentamer composed of alpha and beta subunits. Interacts
CC       with GPHN.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell junction, synapse, postsynaptic cell
CC       membrane; Multi-pass membrane protein. Cell membrane; Multi-pass
CC       membrane protein.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the ligand-gated ionic channel (TC 1.A.9)
CC       family.

RP   TOPOLOGY.
RX   MEDLINE=94344033; PubMed=8065262;
RX   DOI=10.1111/j.1365-2958.1994.tb01033.x;
RA   Reeves P.J., Douglas P., Salmond G.P.C.;
RT   "Beta-lactamase topology probe analysis of the OutO NMePhe peptidase,
RT   and six other Out protein components of the Erwinia carotovora general
RT   secretion pathway apparatus.";
RL   Mol. Microbiol. 12:445-457(1994).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Cleaves type-4 fimbrial leader sequence and methylates
CC       the N-terminal (generally Phe) residue. Involved in a general
CC       secretion pathway (GSP) for the export of proteins. Required for
CC       the translocation of the multiple pectic enzymes.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Typically cleaves a -Gly-|-Phe- bond to
CC       release an N-terminal, basic peptide of 5-8 residues from type IV
CC       prepilin, and then N-methylates the new N-terminal amino group,
CC       the methyl donor being S-adenosyl-L-methionine.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell inner membrane; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the peptidase A24 family.

RN   [8]
RP   TOPOLOGY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RC   STRAIN=K12 / MG1655 / ATCC 47076;
RX   PubMed=15919996; DOI=10.1126/science.1109730;
RA   Daley D.O., Rapp M., Granseth E., Melen K., Drew D., von Heijne G.;
RT   "Global topology analysis of the Escherichia coli inner membrane
RT   proteome.";
RL   Science 308:1321-1323(2005).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: This protein specifically catalyzes the removal of
CC       signal peptides from prolipoproteins.
CC   -!- CATALYTIC ACTIVITY: Release of signal peptides from bacterial
CC       membrane prolipoproteins. Hydrolyzes -Xaa-Yaa-Zaa-|-
CC       (S,diacylglyceryl)Cys-, in which Xaa is hydrophobic (preferably
CC       Leu), and Yaa (Ala or Ser) and Zaa (Gly or Ala) have small,
CC       neutral side chains.
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell inner membrane; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the peptidase A8 family.

RC   STRAIN=K12 / MG1655 / ATCC 47076;

RN   [14]
RP   REVIEW.
RX   MEDLINE=98190797; PubMed=9529892;
RA   Boos W., Shuman H.;
RT   "Maltose/maltodextrin system of Escherichia coli: transport,
RT   metabolism, and regulation.";
RL   Microbiol. Mol. Biol. Rev. 62:204-229(1998).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Part of the binding-protein-dependent transport system
CC       for maltose; probably responsible for the translocation of the
CC       substrate across the membrane.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: The complex is composed of two ATP-binding proteins
CC       (malK), two transmembrane proteins (malG and malF) and a solute-
CC       binding protein (malE).
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell inner membrane; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein; Periplasmic side. Note=A substantial portion of it
CC       protrudes into the periplasmic space.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: When malF EAA loop mutations are made concomitantly
CC       with malG EAA loop mutations, a complete loss of transport and
CC       complex formation is observed, except for the Gly-407. This
CC       suggests that these interaction malF-malG may be important for the
CC       proper assembly and also for the correct function of the
CC       transporter.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the binding-protein-dependent transport
CC       system permease family. MalFG subfamily.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 ABC transmembrane type-1 domain.

CC   Distributed under the Creative Commons Attribution-NoDerivs License

RP   TOPOLOGY [LARGE SCALE ANALYSIS].
RC   STRAIN=K12 / MG1655 / ATCC 47076;
RX   PubMed=15919996; DOI=10.1126/science.1109730;
RA   Daley D.O., Rapp M., Granseth E., Melen K., Drew D., von Heijne G.;
RT   "Global topology analysis of the Escherichia coli inner membrane
RT   proteome.";
RL   Science 308:1321-1323(2005).
CC   -!- FUNCTION: Part of the binding-protein-dependent transport system
CC       for maltose; probably responsible for the translocation of the
CC       substrate across the membrane.
CC   -!- SUBUNIT: The complex is composed of two ATP-binding proteins
CC       (malK), two transmembrane proteins (malG and malF) and a solute-
CC       binding protein (malE).
CC   -!- SUBCELLULAR LOCATION: Cell inner membrane; Multi-pass membrane
CC       protein.
CC   -!- MISCELLANEOUS: When malF EAA loop mutations are made concomitantly
CC       with malG EAA loop mutations, a complete loss of transport and
CC       complex formation is observed. This suggests that the malF-malG
CC       interaction may be important for the proper assembly and also for
CC       the correct function of the transporter.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Belongs to the binding-protein-dependent transport
CC       system permease family. MalFG subfamily.
CC   -!- SIMILARITY: Contains 1 ABC transmembrane type-1 domain.

RP   MUTAGENESIS OF 246-CYS--ARG-251, AND SUBCELLULAR LOCATION.
RX   MEDLINE=96032261; PubMed=7559753; DOI=10.1083/jcb.130.6.1297;
RA   Rohrer J., Schweizer A., Johnson K.F., Kornfeld S.;
